div.p: From William Potter to the general public
H98/8219, unit 972, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

To proof. Or bury?
Letter not found; for the printed version see get details. The letter appears under the headings 'Von Mueller's Grave Monument Fund.' and 'Further earnest appeal for donations.' A photograph of the monument is captioned: 'The Grave Monument is of highly polished grey granite, 23ft. in height, and will stand in the centre of the grave-plot 12ft. square, planted out with choice specimens of the Australian flora with which the name Von Mueller has become imperishably linked: the whole to be enclosed with an ornamental iron railing.' It is signed by the Executors 'Rev. W. Potter, F.R.G.S., Alex. Buttner, M.D., F.R.C.S., H. Buttner, Esq.' "Vonmueller", July 1898.

A year has all but passed since a public appeal was made for donations to carry out the dying wish of Victoria's world-renowned Government Botanist in respect to the erection of a monument over his grave, and still only about one-half of the sum required has been subscribed.

His executors, therefore, are impelled to earnestly appeal to those admirers of his genius and many virtues, municipal councils, public bodies, scientific societies, one-time co-workers in the fields of scientific research, and personal friends who have not as yet contributed to the "Grave Monument Fund" to do so at their earliest convenience, in order that this fitting tribute to the illustrious botanist's memory may, if possible, be unveiled in the St. Kilda Cemetery on the second anniversary day of his death.

The List of Donors will be published with the Baron's biography. The subjoined statement shows the donations that have already come to hand.
The long list printed beneath the letter starts with a donation of £10 from the Royal Geographical Society, London and includes donations from institutions and private individuals throughout Australia and the world, although the majority of the donors were in Melbourne and in Victoria. Include list?

Donations should be addressed to the Rev. W. Potter, "Vonmueller," Arnold street, south Yarra, Melbourne, Australia, who, to guard against loss or mistakes, promptly acknowledges even the smallest amount sent. The words "Grave Monument" should be written across all cheques and postal notes remitted.
